fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • Shelley Armitage – one of three women whom Stephen Griffiths of Bradford is charged with murdering – was named by us as Shelley Armstrong in the caption to a CCTV image published yesterday that showed her walking in the city shortly before she was reported missing in late April (Fatal addiction, page 1). • In today's Guide we refer to the 60th anniversary of the battle and evacuation of Dunkirk. That should be the 70th anniversary (Pick of the day, page 87). • Last Saturday's special guide to Vintage and antiques, 22 May, contained a section on toys – but the wrong shop was named as the source of the toys on show in the large accompanying photograph. Credit should have gone to Pollocks Toy Shop, 44 The Market, Covent Garden, London WC2, 020 7379 7866 (A buyer's guide to... Toys, page 48). In the Clothes and accessories section, a small photo showed lingerie in a shop interior. That was Annie's Vintage Costume and Textile, 12 Camden Passage, London N1, 020 7359 0796 (Stockists, page 32). • Reporting on the first day of the French Open, a piece said the match between France's Jo-Wilfried Tsonga and Germany's Daniel Brands "looked like going to a second tie-break". The final set at the French Open doesn't feature tie-breaks (Dark horse Gulbis falls at the first, 24 May, page 8, Sport). • A report on results of a business-oriented survey that rates cities for quality of life meant to say that Baghdad and Port-au-Prince in Haiti had been placed among the bottom 10, instead of in the top 100 (Vienna placed top of world in quality of life listings, 26 May, page 13, early editions).
